subject: RE: [junit] Re: Using System.out.println("something") ???
msgSnippet: We using logging in order code, but NOT for use during unittesting - thats JUnit s job. The logging is useful once the product has been shipped to the
messageBody:
We using logging in order code, but NOT for use during unittesting - thats
JUnit's job.

The logging is useful once the product has been shipped to the customers,
because then they can send us the log file when/if they discover a bug.

It should be noted: We only log actions that occur at system/component
boundaries,

eg When a remote client invokes a command upon the server.

The remote client will record a logging statement saying "Performing XXXX
command upon server XXX with values: A, B, C, etc..." (or something like
that)

The server will record a logging statement saying "Actioning command XXXX
with values: A, B, C, etc... from remote client ABC" (or something like
that)

We don't use logging as a means of stack tracing a running application.


> -----Original Message-----
> From: javainsel [mailto:javainsel@...]
> Sent: 12 May 2003 14:35
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Re: Using System.out.println("something") ???
>
>
> > - you would like to have a println in your production code, use a
> logger (log4J,
> > commons-logging) instead
> >
> > -Vladimir
>
> What would you log?
>
> Or what is recommended to log?
>
> We want to use logging but we have no idea what we should log in
> JUnit tests.
>
> Are there general ideas?
>
>
